thread.title: Tube strike 2017: Waterloo & City line drivers defy walkout but Central line 'incredibly busy' during strike
thread.title_full: Tube strike 2017: Waterloo & City line drivers defy walkout but Central line 'incredibly busy' during strike

author: dick Murray
title: Tube strike 2017: Waterloo & City line drivers defy walkout but Central line 'incredibly busy' during strike
text:
Thursday 26 January 2017 09:58 BST Click to followThe Evening Standard Crowds: Commuters have had to find alternative routes into work Dhaval Gore 
Tube train drivers on the Waterloo & City line defied an RMT strike call on Thursday and turned up for work. 
The line, which operates a direct link between Waterloo mainline and Bank stations and used by more than 32,000 Square Mile commuters a day, was late starting service but then staff turned up. 
But the British Transport Police tweeted to say that the Central line was "incredibly busy" as a result of strike action on the route. 
A senior Tube source said of the Waterloo and City line: “We didn’t expect this. We have had a good service during the morning peak. We ran the full five train service because drivers turned up for duty. 
"This was a major relief for thousands of passengers and we thank those drivers." Strike action: Commuters queue for Tube services during a 24-hour walkout (Andrew Phoenix) 
The RMT ordered a 24-hour strike today, which began at 9pm last night, among its Central line drivers in protest over what it claims was the “forced” move of eight of its members to different train depots. 
London Underground warned on Wednesday the walkout would also prevent the Waterloo & City line (known as The Drain) from operating all day because it uses the same staff pool. 
The strike, however, meant sections of the busy Central line, used by up to 800,000 passengers a day, were without service. 
The disruption was far worse than predicted by Tube chiefs with no service east of Leytonstone or between Marble Arch and White City west bound. Rush hour commuters face havoc after Tube walkout 
There were severe delays over the rest of the line. 
The Central line service will remain uncertain all day with Tube bosses only able to run trains depending on last minute driver availability. 
RMT pickets were on duty at the Hainault, Leytonstone and Loughton train crew depots persuading their colleagues, including those of the rival Aslef union not in the dispute, from reporting for duty. 
The strike is in protest at what the RMT claims is a move to “force” eight of its driver members currently based in the east of London to other depots, including Earl’s Court. Read more
